text: hearing is critical
yet it is often taken for granted this
important sense allows us to respond to
sound in our environment keeping us safe
from danger it's also crucial for
communicating with spoken language and
appreciating music
[Music]
the winners of the 2018 Kavli Prize in
neuroscience are James Hudspeth Robert
feta place and christine petit for their
groundbreaking research unraveling the
mysteries of how we hear these three
scientists have taken really novel
methodological approaches to hearing
that include very sophisticated
biophysics and cutting-edge human
genetics to unravel the cellular and the
molecular mechanisms that enable those
hair cells to transform sound into
electrical impulses in the brain I think
from this work we understand how
precious these hair cells are if the
hair cell gets damaged their ability to
transform sound into those electrical
impulses is blocked and that results in
profound losses of hearing or even
complete deafness James Hudspeth
discovered that these sensory receptors
in our ears actively twitch creating a
built-in amplifier system
James has both has performed these
amazing biophysical experiments where he
found that the movement of the hair
bundles relative to one another
creates a mechanical force that actually
pops open the channels that let
potassium ions flow into the cell and
that's what initiates the electrical
signal that's the foundation of hearing
itself meanwhile Christine petit took a
very different approach to understanding
hearing fatigue work with doctors in
places like Syria in Jordan where
profound deafness is prevalent in large
families she's focused on families with
congenital hereditary deafness with a
very early onset by studying the genes
that have been altered in those families
she's actually identified almost two
dozen different genes that are required
for normal hearing and amazingly all but
one of those genes is actually needed in
the hair cells themselves
Robert fetta place was one of the first
people to record hair cells in the inner
ear he found they are individually tuned
to different frequencies of sound robert
Feder plays found that cells that detect
different frequencies are distributed in
different positions through the spiral
of the inner ear Hudspeth fetta place
and petites
innovative research is significant it
has the potential to benefit the 5% of
the world's population who suffer from
disabling hearing loss
[Music]
[Music]
